## üìã OVERVIEW

**Objective**: Master R for data science through collaborative weekly book reviews\
**Primary Resource**: *R for Data Science (1st Edition)* by Hadley Wickham & Garrett Grolemund\
**Duration**: 25 weeks (February 4 ‚Äì July 22, 2026)\
**Format**: 60-minute weekly meetups with rotating leadership\
**Group Size**: 14 participants\
**Level**: Beginner to Intermediate

------------------------------------------------------------------------

## üéØ LEARNING GOALS

By the end of this course, participants will be able to:

1.  **Import & wrangle data** ‚Äì Load, clean, reshape messy datasets into analysis-ready format
2.  **Transform & explore** ‚Äì Use dplyr to filter, summarize, and join datasets; conduct EDA
3.  **Visualize effectively** ‚Äì Create exploratory and publication-ready plots with ggplot2
4.  **Write functions & automate** ‚Äì Build reusable functions; iterate efficiently with purrr
5.  **Model data** ‚Äì Fit simple and complex models to understand relationships
6.  **Communicate results** ‚Äì Generate reproducible reports with R Markdown
7.  **Apply to epidemiology** ‚Äì Use all skills on real STH surveillance and research data

## üìñ BOOK ORDER vs. OUR LEARNING SEQUENCE

### **Why We're Reordering the Chapters**

The **R for Data Science book is published in this order**: Visualization (Ch 1) ‚Üí Transformation (Ch 3) ‚Üí Wrangling (Ch 7‚Äì13) ‚Üí Programming (Ch 14‚Äì17) ‚Üí Modeling (Ch 18‚Äì20) ‚Üí Communication (Ch 21‚Äì24).

However, **this order isn't optimal for beginners learning epidemiology**. The book's authors acknowledge this in their Preface:

> "Starting with data ingest and tidying is suboptimal because 80% of the time it's routine and boring, and the other 20% of the time it's weird and frustrating. That's a bad place to start learning a new subject! Instead, we'll start with visualization and transformation of data that's already been imported and tidied."

**The problem:** Chapter 1 (ggplot2) assumes clean data exists. But beginners need to **import, clean, and reshape data FIRST** before they can visualize or analyze it.

### **Our Reordered Learning Sequence**

We follow the **natural real-world epidemiological workflow** instead of the book's ordering:

```{r, echo=FALSE}
sequence <- data.frame(
  Phase = c("1. Foundation", "2. Wrangling", "3. Exploration", 
            "4. Programming", "5. Modeling", "6. Communication"),
  Weeks = c("1‚Äì3", "4‚Äì13", "14‚Äì15", "16‚Äì18", "19‚Äì21", "22‚Äì25"),
  `Our Order` = c("First", "Second", "Third", "Fourth", "Fifth", "Sixth"),
  `Book Chapters` = c("2, 4, 6 (Workflow)", 
                     "7‚Äì13 (Import, Tidy, Transform, Join, Handle types)", 
                     "5, 1 (EDA, Visualization)", 
                     "15, 16, 17 (Functions, Vectors, Iteration)", 
                     "18, 19, 20 (Model Basics, Building, Many Models)", 
                     "21‚Äì24 (R Markdown, Graphics, Formats, Workflow)"),
  Purpose = c("Learn RStudio, organize work, set up projects BEFORE coding",
             "Get messy data into analysis-ready format",
             "Explore clean data visually & statistically",
             "Write reusable code & automate workflows",
             "Fit & evaluate statistical models",
             "Document findings & create reproducible reports")
)

kable(sequence, escape = FALSE, booktabs = TRUE) %>%
  kable_styling(full_width = FALSE, bootstrap_options = c("striped", "hover")) %>%
  column_spec(c(2), bold = TRUE)
```

### **Why This Order Works Better**

‚úÖ **Motivation**: Learn foundational tools first, then apply them to real problems\
‚úÖ **Real-world**: Follow the actual epidemiological analysis workflow\
‚úÖ **Practical**: Work with messy data early; clean it before analyzing\
‚úÖ **Confidence**: See tangible results at each step (import ‚Üí clean ‚Üí analyze ‚Üí visualize)\
‚úÖ **Less frustration**: Don't start with "boring" wrangling; build to it naturally

### **Leader Responsibilities**

Each leader should: 
- **Read chapter thoroughly** 1 week in advance (3‚Äì4 hours) 
- **Prepare 2‚Äì3 worked code examples** to demo live (copy-paste ready) 
- **Identify 3‚Äì5 key concepts** that will be discussed 
- **Note common confusions** or tricky sections from your own reading 
- **Bring 2‚Äì3 discussion questions** to engage the group 
- **Help troubleshoot** participant questions & coding errors 
- **Share practical epi applications** of the chapter content

**For Co-Leaders (3 toughest sessions):** 
- **Divide responsibilities**: One leads first half, other leads second half  
- **Coordinate prep work**: Meet 1 week before to align on content & demos 
- **Share code examples**: Create demo scripts together for consistency

### **Leadership Rotation (Random Selection by Number 1‚Äì14)**

1. Each person selects a number between **1 and 14** at the start of the course

## üìù WEEKLY PREPARATION (~**4 hours**)

Participants should dedicate approximately **4 hours per week**:

### **Before the Meeting** (3.5 hours)

1.  **Read & understand chapter** (**2 hours**)
    - Skim introduction for context (15 min)
    - Read thoroughly with code examples (1 hr)
    - Run **all** examples in RStudio (45 min)  
    - Take notes on key concepts (15 min)

2.  **Practice exercises** (**1 hour**)
    - Work through **5‚Äì7 exercises** at chapter end
    - Run code locally; save working examples
    - Debug errors independently first
    - Note 2‚Äì3 challenges for discussion

3.  **Prepare questions & review** (**30 minutes**)
    - List **2‚Äì3 specific questions** 
    - Review epi applications from syllabus
    - Preview next week's chapter overview

### **After the Meeting** (**30 minutes**)
- Review meeting notes & code demos
- Re-run 1‚Äì2 examples from leader
- Update personal code library
